title: 79/297. Strategic heritage plan of the United Nations Office at Geneva

 Resolution adopted by the General Assembly 
on 30 June 2025 
 
 
 
 
[on the report of the Fifth Committee (A/79/652/Add.2, para. 6)] 
 
 
 79/297. Strategic heritage plan of the United Nations Office at Geneva 
 
 
 
The General Assembly, 
 
Recalling part XI of its resolution 64/243 of 24 December 2009, section VII of 
its resolution 66/247 of 24 December 2011, section V of its resolution 68/247 A of 
27 December 2013, sections III and VII of its resolution 69/262 of 29 December 2014, 
section X of its resolution 70/248 A of 23 December 2015, section XVIII of its 
resolution 71/272 A of 23 December 2016, section XVI of its resolution 72/262 A of 
24 December 2017, section XIII of its resolution 73/279 A of 22 December 2018, 
section VII of its resolution 74/263 of 27 December 2019, section IX of its resolution 
75/253 A of 31 December 2020, section XVIII of its resolution 76/246 A of 
24 December 2021, section VI of its resolution 77/263 A of 30 December 2022, 
section XIX of its resolution 78/253 of 22 December 2023 and section XVII of its 
resolution 79/258 A of 24 December 2024,  
 
Having considered the update to the eleventh annual progress report of the 
Secretary-General on the strategic heritage plan of the United Nations Office at 
Geneva1 and the related report of the Advisory Committee on Administrative and 
Budgetary Questions,2 
 
1. 
Takes note of the report of the Secretary-General;  
 
2. 
Endorses the conclusions and recommendations contained in the report of 
the Advisory Committee;  
 
3. 
Welcomes the continued support of the Government of Switzerland for the 
construction project in Geneva;

4. 
Stresses the importance of close coordination between the strategic 
heritage plan project team and the Secretariat in New York, in particular the Global 
Asset Management Policy Service, to ensure success in all aspects of the project;  
 
5. 
Also stresses the importance of effective governance, oversight, 
transparency and accountability in the management of the project to ensure that the 
project objectives are achieved on time and within budget;  
 
6. 
Requests the Secretary-General to continue to ensure that the procurement 
of goods and services for the construction project is carried out in strict compliance 
with the existing regulations, rules and relevant provisions of General Assembly 
resolutions governing procurement in the United Nations;  
 
7. 
Also requests the Secretary-General to ensure that the project team takes 
vendors, notably from developing countries and countries with economies in transition, 
fully into account and to report on the specific steps taken and progress achieved in 
the context of increasing procurement opportunities for vendors from developing 
countries and countries with economies in transition in the implementation of the 
strategic heritage plan;  
 
8. 
Further requests the Secretary-General to ensure that all activities promote 
cost-efficiency and transparency, are implemented within existing resources and in 
accordance with the United Nations legislative framework, including the Financial 
Regulations and Rules, while maintaining full accountability to the General 
Assembly;  
 
9. 
Requests the Secretary-General to ensure maximum utilization of 
building H;  
 
10. Also requests the Secretary-General to ensure that any change that affects 
the scope of the strategic heritage plan project is presented for the consideration and 
decision of the General Assembly;  
 
11. 
Notes with concern that the project has used a total of 92,917,000 Swiss 
francs in contingencies to date, and strongly reiterates that the use of the contingency 
provision should be tightly monitored and limited to the absolute minimum;  
 
12. Decides to approve a revised estimated cost of the strategic heritage plan 
in the maximum amount of 924,244,000 Swiss francs to implement the scope of the 
project as approved in its resolution 70/248 A; 
 
13. Requests the Secretary-General to complete, within the revised budget, as 
set out in paragraph 12 above, and within the revised timeline for the project, the 
remaining construction elements that are both interdependent and required for code 
compliance and excluding items that are independent and beyond code compliance; 
 
14. Also requests the Secretary-General to ensure the substantial completion 
of the strategic heritage plan by 31 December 2027, and decides that any further 
increase in costs of the strategic heritage plan beyond the approved budget should be 
funded from voluntary contributions; 
 
15. Stresses that any increase to the maximum overall budget must be 
approved by the General Assembly before entering into corresponding financial 
commitments;  
 
16. Recalls paragraph 41 of the report of the Advisory Committee;  
 
17. Regrets further delays incurred in the project, and requests the Secretary-
General to make utmost and every effort to strictly abide by the approved revised 
budget and schedule, including through tight cost control, regular and proactive 
review of risks, value engineering and cost-saving measures, notes such measures

undertaken to date, and looks forward to receiving further information in his next 
progress report; 
 
18. Requests the Secretary-General to ensure maximum utilization of the 
renovated historical buildings, including by enabling Member States to fully utilize 
the Secretariat’s common meeting rooms;  
 
19. Also requests the Secretary-General to avoid any potential duplication 
between the strategic heritage plan and the alteration, improvement and major 
maintenance of the United Nations Office at Geneva under section 33 of the regular 
budget;  
 
20. Appreciates the existing voluntary contributions received from Member 
States to finance the strategic heritage plan, and requests the Secretary-General to 
remain proactive in seeking both voluntary and in-kind contributions from Member 
States, as well as donations by private entities, in full compliance with all relevant 
rules and regulations of the Organization and agreements related to donations for the 
strategic heritage plan, and to provide detailed information on this matter in the 
context of his next progress report;  
 
21. Requests the Secretary-General to make all possible efforts to mobilize 
further voluntary contributions, aiming for at least 24 million Swiss francs to help to 
offset the total cost of the renovation of building B and conference rooms in building 
E, in full compliance with all relevant rules and regulations of the Organization and 
agreements related to donations, and notes that the appropriations for Member States 
under section 33 will be reduced according to voluntary contributions received;  
 
22. Also requests the Secretary-General to provide more information on the 
use of conference space at the United Nations Office at Geneva by non-governmental 
organizations in the context of his next progress report on the strategic heritage plan 
at the main part of its eightieth session;  
 
23. Further requests the Secretary-General to ensure that remaining 
recommendations of the Board of Auditors are implemented fully and expeditiously;  
 
24. Requests the Secretary-General to continue documenting best practices 
and lessons learned from capital construction projects, including value engineering, 
multistage request for proposals and the use of local materials and knowledge, and to 
consider their application, as appropriate, to ensure that the objectives of the projects 
are achieved within the approved budget and timeline.  
 
81st plenary meeting 
30 June 2025
